If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` being odd is equivalent to `n` not being even. In other words, a natural number is odd if and only if it is not even. Here, a number is considered odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some `k`, and a number is considered even if it can be written as `r + r` for some `r`.

A natural number `n` is equivalent to being odd, as defined in Lean 4, if and only if `n` modulo 2 equals 1, which is equivalent to `n` being expressible as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`.

description: This theorem establishes an equivalence for a natural number `n` to be considered odd in two different ways. A natural number `n` is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some number `k`. Thus, the theorem asserts that any natural number fits one of these two definitions.

A natural number is odd if and only if its residue modulo 4 is 1 or 3.

statement: theorem Nat.odd_mod_four_iff : ∀ {n : ℕ}, n % 2 = 1 ↔ n % 4 = 1 ∨ n % 4 = 3 := by sorry
name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`
description: This theorem states that a natural number is odd if and only if its remainder when divided by 4 is either 1 or 3. In other words, it characterizes odd numbers in terms of their residues modulo 4.
concise-description: A natural number is odd if and only if its residue modulo 4 is 1 or 3.

For any natural number `n`, `n + 1` is even if and only if `n` is odd.

name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.13
docString: For any natural number `n`, `n + 1` is even if and only if `n` is odd.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the number `n + 1` is even if and only if `n` is not even. In other words, if `n` is an odd number, then `n + 1` is an even number, and vice versa.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) = (Even m ↔ Even n)

A natural number is even if and only if it is not odd. Equivalently, a natural number is even if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number, and it is odd if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number plus 1.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Even n ↔ ¬Odd n
statement: theorem Nat.even_iff_not_odd : ∀ {n : ℕ}, Even n ↔ ¬Odd n := by sorry
name: Nat.even_iff_not_odd
description: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` is even if and only if `n` is not odd. Here, a number is defined as being even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as being odd if it can be represented as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`. In other words, a natural number cannot be both even and odd simultaneously.
concise-description: A natural number is even if and only if it is not odd. Equivalently, a natural number is even if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number, and it is odd if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number plus 1.

If a natural number `n` is odd and another natural number `a` is even, then the remainder `n % a` is an odd number.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Odd n → Even a → Odd (n % a)
statement: theorem Odd.mod_even : ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Odd n → Even a → Odd (n % a) := by sorry
name: Odd.mod_even
docString: If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd.
description: This theorem states that if a natural number `n` is odd and another natural number `a` is even, then the remainder when `n` is divided by `a` (denoted as `n % a`) is also odd. Specifically, in mathematical terms, this means that if `n = 2*k + 1` for some natural number `k` (which makes `n` odd), and `a = r + r` for some natural number `r` (which makes `a` even), then there exists a natural number `m` such that `n % a = 2*m + 1`, i.e., `n % a` is odd.
concise-description: If a natural number `n` is odd and another natural number `a` is even, then the remainder `n % a` is an odd number.

If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Even (n % a) ↔ Even n)
name: Even.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

For every natural number `n`, the oddness of `n` and `n+1` are opposite.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), n.succ.bodd = !n.bodd
name: Nat.bodd_succ
docString: For every natural number `n`, the oddness of `n` and `n+1` are opposite.

Here, a number is defined as being even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as being odd if it can be represented as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`. In other words, a natural number cannot be both even and odd simultaneously.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Even n ↔ ¬Odd n
name: Nat.even_iff_not_odd

Here, a number is defined as being even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as being odd if it can be represented as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`. If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString:
If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

In `Fin n`, all elements are odd for odd `n`,
otherwise an element is odd iff its `Fin.val` value is odd.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ} [inst : NeZero n] {k : Fin n}, Odd k ↔ Odd n ∨ Odd ↑k
name: Fin.odd_iff
docString:
In `Fin n`, all elements are odd for odd `n`,
otherwise an element is odd iff its `Fin.val` value is odd.

A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 3 → Even (padicValNat q n)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff
docString:
A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)
